channel.title: Networking Frameworks
channel.description:
Just curious if anyone here has decided to switch up their base using any of the following and why:
[code] Grizzly
Grizzly framework has been designed to help developers to take advantage of the Java™ NIO API. Originally developed under the GlassFish umbrella, the framework is now available as a standalone project. Grizzly goals is to help developers to build scalable and robust servers using NIO. Netty 3
The new version of Netty Trustin Lee is working on now. The Netty project is an effort to provide an asynchronous event-driven network application framework and tools for rapid development of maintainable high performance and high scalability protocol servers and clients. NIO Framework
The NIO Framework is a library on top of NIO that hides most of the complexity of plain NIO. With the NIO Framework you can implement high-performance Java network applications without having to deal with all the nasty details of NIO. The issues above are resolved while the performance is preserved. QuickServer
QuickServer is an open source Java library/framework for quick creation of robust multi-client TCP server applications. QuickServer provides an abstraction over the ServerSocket, Socket and other network and input output classes and it eases the creation of powerful network servers. xSocket
xSocket is a easy to use NIO-based library to build high performance, highly scalable network applications. It supports writing client-side applications as well as server-side applications in an intuitive way. Issues like low level NIO selector programming, connection pool management, connection timeout detection or fragmented buffer reads are encapsulated by xSocket. [/code]
I do know xEnt attempted a Netty re-make, but never finished. After reading, I've come to the conclusion that MINA does have more features (which aren't really used by a current RSCD build), at the cost of slower processing speed. All of them have their pros/cons, and performance may be near similar (some more than others).
Also, on a side note: Updated the mysql-connector library from the generic 4.* version, RSCD and RSCA used (quite a bit of bug/performance fixes). Thoughts/spam/flame?

item.title: Networking Frameworks
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“object, post:47, topic:368135”]Or better yet, drop all code and rewrite from scratch.

Instead of keeping this project as just one huge project, consider separating the major parts into smaller much more manageable projects. For instance, Application Layer (logic would be put here), Domain Layer (the model of the world and everything to it would be put here) and Infrastructure Layer (database-access etc. would be put here).

More on-topic: To change between MINA, Netty, IO, NIO or whatever else you prefer to use, should require as little as changing one class implementation (use of the Strategy-pattern would work here). This together with IoC (for instance Spring Framework) or even the Java ServiceLoader would work great, and the choice could be made by anyone, not just programmers, by simply changing some XML file or adding some new Jar file to the classpath while removing the old one.[/quote]
he is rite… decouple as much as u can

Read full topic

item.title: Networking Frameworks
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Or better yet, drop all code and rewrite from scratch.

Instead of keeping this project as just one huge project, consider separating the major parts into smaller much more manageable projects. For instance, Application Layer (logic would be put here), Domain Layer (the model of the world and everything to it would be put here) and Infrastructure Layer (database-access etc. would be put here).

More on-topic: To change between MINA, Netty, IO, NIO or whatever else you prefer to use, should require as little as changing one class implementation (use of the Strategy-pattern would work here). This together with IoC (for instance Spring Framework) or even the Java ServiceLoader would work great, and the choice could be made by anyone, not just programmers, by simply changing some XML file or adding some new Jar file to the classpath while removing the old one.

Read full topic

item.title: Networking Frameworks
item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

[quote=“Intoxication, post:44, topic:368135”]Oops I forgot about this.

Peter since your source is a lot more modified than RSCDv25, it’s hard to compare. On my VPS, RSCA’s released source (without the 2gig memory reserve), it comes out to be about a 800 - a gig. RSCDv25 is like 500-600MB on my VPS also. I could give a benchmark test on both servers if you’d like, but it really wouldn’t prove anything since there would be 0 players online for those X days.

Off topic: Did KO9 release an older version of RSCA?[/quote]

No, KO9 didn’t release an older version of RSCA, I’m just that awesome.

Protip on how to make RSCAs source more stable: drop all of xEnts code.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

[quote=“Peeter, post:41, topic:368135”] USER PID %CPU %MEM VSZ RSS TTY STAT START TIME COMMAND root 23031 0.0 3.3 769900 70260 ? Sl Nov14 0:47 /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.6.0-openjdk-1.6.0.0/jre/bin/java -Xms128m -Xmx512m -classpath /home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/mina.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/xpp3.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/slf4j.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/xstream.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/mysql-connector.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/hex-string.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/dq.jar org.darkquest.ls.Server ls.conf root 23095 2.7 14.4 793516 299692 ? Sl Nov14 154:06 /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.6.0-openjdk-1.6.0.0/jre/bin/java -Xms128m -Xmx512m -classpath /home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/mina.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/xpp3.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/slf4j.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/xstream.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/mysql-connector.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/lib/hex-string.jar:/home/darkq/DarkQuest/dq.jar org.darkquest.gs.Server server.conf f2p no

That’s after 3 days of uptime. Please take note that when the GS starts, memory usage goes up to 340mb. After javas garbage collector cleans up unused shit, it drops to 290.[/quote]

clearly the PID’s are different, opps didn’t notice that you are running 2 java programs there. But yeah it’s a system hog. Too much same data loaded every instance is my guess, should just load that data statically and pass instance for usage.

Here is a log of running my server for 46? days straight i believe

PID	%CPU	%MEM	Command	Nice	Pri	RSS	Stat	Time	User
19543	0.0	0.1	 java -classpath .:mysql-connector-java-3.0.17-ga-bin.jar Server	0	21	46976	Sl	00:19:47	root

it’s not good either it has a total of 30-50 users online 24\7, although it’s not RSC but RS2 still it leaks memory. Started off at 32000 RSS now its up to 46976 and in the beginning day 1… i can support exactly the same amount of users at 33000 RSS as I am supporting now on day 46 yet memory keeps going up, so a restart is immanent, which pisses me off.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“Intoxication, post:40, topic:368135”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=464281.msg3401717#msg3401717 date=1289971572]
As for not contributing, my point was that it’s dumb to shoot down the guy who rightly suggests that you should know where your performance issues are rather than randomly deciding for no reason that MINA is your problem because some guy on the internet said so and then raging at anyone who calls you out on being wrong.
[/quote]

I’m pretty sure I have my reasons straight. You’re assuming I’m/we’re saying Netty will fix all our problems, and we have never said that, not even once. If you cannot bother to read, or cannot comprehend what we’re saying then you don’t belong here.

Your bottleneck isn’t MINA, it’s RSCD. Until you fix RSCD you will see little to no improvements by switching out MINA for Netty…

You’re mentally retarded if you don’t know that you need to profile your application before you try and optimize it.

You’re wrong here. End of story.

Oh really, please provide me with some data to back that up.

Provide me with some data that MINA isn’t the problem.

…

He’s not going to waste his time, so why should I?[/quote]

item.dc:creator: @The_AFKer The_AFKer
item.description:
@The_AFKer wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:36, topic:368135”]Perhaps you should understand sarcasm, my point is that MINA is quite clearly an event driven framework too, you tool.

EDIT: As for not contributing, my point was that it’s dumb to shoot down the guy who rightly suggests that you should know where your performance issues are rather than randomly deciding for no reason that MINA is your problem because some guy on the internet said so and then raging at anyone who calls you out on being wrong.[/quote]

Good for you, you have a bad way of getting a point across on a board full of “dumb people”.

I’m raging that some of you can’t read, I’ve stated about 5 times now that MINA was not the entire issue, and even went as far as saying that it may or may not improve; I don’t mind trying to argue my view on it, even it comes off as retarded to some of you. As for profiling the application, I’ve barely begun at the foundation, as I was only stating issues relating to RSCD not whether or not MINA was the full fault of it.

If you read the original question, it was clear that I was merely asking if people had used different frameworks, how this became about me and my views on approach, was due to CodeForFame’s argumentative nature.

item.title: Networking Frameworks
item.dc:creator: @The_AFKer The_AFKer
item.description:
@The_AFKer wrote:

Holy shit, you people actually thought I meant that simply plugging Netty as is would change things? That wouldn’t even be possible, obviously a lot of the current core would need to change to even make use of Netty’s features… considering it’s event-driven. Maybe think things through before assuming…

@Pets: I never said MINA was the full fault of this, but it doesn’t necessary make the best use of it.

Read: http://www.gnu-darwin.org/www001/src/ports/devel/ocaml-equeue/work/equeue-2.1.4/doc/users-guide/html/c494.html

Scheduling: Multi-threaded programs sometimes lead to situations where there are many runnable threads. Despite the capabilities of the operating system, every modern hardware has the restriction that it performs badly if the code to execute is wide-spread over the whole memory. This is mainly caused by limited cache memory. Many operating systems are not well enough designed to efficiently get around this bottleneck.

Read full topic

item.title: Networking Frameworks
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:21, topic:368135”]Your bottleneck isn’t MINA, it’s RSCD. Until you fix RSCD you will see little to no improvements by switching out MINA for Netty…

You’re mentally retarded if you don’t know that you need to profile your application before you try and optimize it.[/quote]

I have to agree with Icode. Although netty is better than mina, the problem with rsc is the actual source. Switching to netty without changing the source itself and expecting a good performance change is not gonna happen.

But generally speaking in an ideal situation, netty is win.

Read full topic
